channel.title: What's Up? on Time for a Change
channel.description: Recent content in What's Up? on Time for a Change

item.title: Siberian tiger's paw prints spotted for the first time in 50 years and more.
item.description: Russian residents spotted paw prints belonging to a Siberian tiger in Siberia for the first time in 50 years, indicating that the big cats are recovering.

item.title: Portugal forbids employers to contact workers after hours and more.
item.description: In Portugal, it is now illegal for employers to contact their employees outside of their regular hours. This rule echoes a similar one that France passed in 2017, giving workers the right to ignore after-hours business emails.

item.title: Spanish drivers can exchange old car for a free transit pass and more.
item.description: In Barcelona, drivers can exchange their old car for a 3-year free transit pass. Since public transit infrastructure already exists, promoting such incentives is significantly cheaper for the city than advertising electric vehicles.

item.title: Coldplay will harness their fans' energy and more.
item.description: For their next World Tour, music band Coldplay will harness their fans’ energy to make their concerts more sustainable. Indeed, the band will capture the energy of dancing fans through kinetic flooring.

item.title: Paris slashed its buildings energy bill and more.
item.description: Paris pledged to reduce its public housings’ energy consumption by 60% by 2030. After a decade of efforts, including changing the insulation and renovating the heating systems and electrical wiring, some of the largest buildings already witnessed a 47% drop in their energy bill.

item.title: Nobel prize in physics for two climate modellers and more.
item.description: Syukuro Manabe and Klaus Hasselmann jointly won the 2021 Nobel prize in physics. These two climate modellers laid the foundations of our current understanding of carbon dioxide’s impact on the climate since the 1960s and 1980s respectively.

item.title: UNESCO declared the Amazon of Europe a Biosphere Reserve and more.
item.description: UNESCO recently declared the Amazon of Europe a Biosphere Reserve. This one-million-hectare area spans 5 Eastern European countries (Austria, Slovenia, Croatia, Hungary and Serbia) and is one of Europe’s richest landscapes in terms of species and habitats.

item.title: Australian bushfires yielded unexpected benefits and more.
item.description: In Australia, the recent bushfires might have yielded significant environmental benefits. Indeed, researchers noticed that a tiny algae plant used the ashes that fell into the ocean to flourish, offsetting the fire’s carbon emissions.

item.title: Recycling gets you a free trip on the metro in Rome and more.
item.description: You can get a free trip on the metro in Rome by recycling 30 plastic bottles. During its first six weeks of operation, the Ricicli + Viaggi (Recycle + Travel) initiative processed over 350,000 plastic bottles and offered €17,500 worth of free travel.

item.title: Up to $340 million in new funding to support Indigenous-led conservation projects and more.
item.description: The Canadian government will provide up to $340 million in new funding to support Indigenous-led conservation projects over the next five years.

item.title: India has built 34,000 km of roads out of plastic waste and more.
item.description: India has built more than 34,000 km of roads out of plastic waste so far. Each km of these cheaper and stronger roads uses the equivalent of 1 million plastic bags.

item.title: The humpback whale population up to historic levels and more.
item.description: On the brink of extinction in the 70s, the humpback whale has since recovered, and the population is now almost at the same level as before whaling began in the 1700s, thanks to a ban on commercial whaling in 1986.

item.title: Bhutan is the world’s first carbon-negative country and more.
item.description: Bhutan is the world’s first carbon-negative country. By incorporating sustainability into its national identity, this Asian country achieved this feat while becoming one of the world’s happiest countries.

item.title: Belize's barrier reef is no longer in danger and more.
item.description: Thanks to an oil drilling moratorium, development restrictions, and fishing reforms, Belize’s barrier reef is no longer on UNESCO’s List of World Heritage in Danger.

item.title: Female youth literacy is up worldwide and more.
item.description: Female youth literacy worldwide was up to 92% in 2019, 20% above the 77% level in 1975. UK’s woodland cover is back to medieval levels, thanks to the country’s “rewilding” policy.
